{{cpp/container/inplace_vector/title|emplace_back}}
{{cpp/container/inplace_vector/navbar}}
{{ddcl|since=c++26|
template&lt; class... Args &gt;
constexpr reference emplace_back( Args&amp;&amp;... args );
}}

Appends a new element to the end of the container. Typically, the element is constructed using placement-{{c/core|new}} to construct the element in-place at the location provided by the container. The arguments {{c|args...}} are forwarded to the constructor as {{c|std::forward&lt;Args&gt;(args)...}}.

{{cpp/container/note_iterator_invalidation|inplace_vector|emplace_back}}

===Parameters===
{{par begin}}
{{par|args|arguments to forward to the constructor of the element}}
{{par hreq}}
{{par req named|T|EmplaceConstructible}}
{{par end}}

===Return value===
{{rlpf|back}}, i.e. a reference to the inserted element.

===Complexity===
Constant.

===Exceptions===
* {{lc|std::bad_alloc}} if {{c|1=size() == capacity()}} before invocation.
* Any exception thrown by initialization of the inserted element.
{{cpp/strong exception safety guarantee|plural=yes}}

===Example===
{{example
|code=
#include &lt;inplace_vector&gt;
#include &lt;new&gt;
#include &lt;print&gt;
#include &lt;string&gt;
#include &lt;utility&gt;

int main()
{
    std::inplace_vector&lt;std::pair&lt;std::string, std::string&gt;, 2&gt; fauna;
    std::string dog{"\N{DOG}"};

    fauna.emplace_back("\N{CAT}", dog);
    fauna.emplace_back("\N{CAT}", std::move(dog));
    std::println("fauna = {}", fauna);

    try
    {
        fauna.emplace_back("\N{BUG}", "\N{BUG}"); // throws: there is no space
    }
    catch(const std::bad_alloc&amp; ex)
    {
        std::println("{}", ex.what());
    }
    std::println("fauna = {}", fauna);
}
|p=true
|output=
fauna = [("ğŸˆ", "ğŸ•"), ("ğŸˆ", "ğŸ•")]
std::bad_alloc
fauna = [("ğŸˆ", "ğŸ•"), ("ğŸˆ", "ğŸ•")]
}}
